pros:
All residency programs are super busy with crazy work hours. YWIMRP isn’t that busy and we have satisfactory time off. Clinic isn’t busy at all comparing to other residencies.
No scut work. Residents do not draw blood. 
Faculty members are very supportive and involved in your professional growth.
Teaching attending physician is available at any time. Attending is in the hospital all day. Sometimes they go to the ED with you to see a patient. They teach you for 2-3 hr during morning rounds daily on floors/ICU and 30-60 min. during evening sign off. 
ICU staff is just amazing. RNs are wonderful knowledgeable and hard-working. ICU attendings are wonderful! A lot of teaching during busy ICU blocks.
Rotations at Yale Hospital are possible for specialties.
The program is very very very diverse and inclusive. They hire from everywhere in the world. But there isn’t much LGBTQ.
There are opportunities to rent home nearby the hospital. Prices are 1000-1500 per month for 2-3 bedroom apartment. 
There is a small gym in the hospital, 10$ (Ten bucks) per year.
cons:
Night shifts are 80-90 hr per week and ICU/floor days 60-70 hr. No life style of course during these blocks. It is just “hospital to bedroom” life. 
7-8 months of ICU during the categorical training. This is WAY above you need for IM.
Need to cross cover overnight. There is no learning during cross cover.
20-50% of Telemetry and floor RNs should improve their communication skills with physicians.
I think there isn’t enough outpatient learning. No outpatient procedures training. 
Hospital does not sponsor J1 waiver.
